Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: SI2-SSE - A Plug-and-Play Software Platform of Robotics-Inspired Algorithms for Modeling Biomolecular Structures and Motions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop a novel plug-and-play platform of open-source software elements to advance algorithmic research in molecular biology. The focus is on addressing the algorithmic impasse faced by computational chemists and biophysicists in structure-function related problems involving dynamic biomolecules central to our biology. The software platform resulting from this project provides the critical software infrastructure to support transformative research in molecular biology and computer science that benefits society at large by advancing our modeling capabilities and in turn our understanding of the role of biomolecules in critical mechanisms in a living and diseased cell.

The project addresses the current impasse on the length and time scales that can be afforded in biomolecular modeling and simulation. It does so by integrating cutting-edge knowledge from two different research communities, computational chemists and biophysicists focused on detailed physics-based simulations, and AI researchers focused on efficient search and optimization algorithms. The software elements integrate sophisticated energetic models and molecular representations with powerful search and optimization algorithms for complex modular systems inspired from robot motion planning. The plug-and-play feature of the software platform supports putting together novel algorithms, such as wrapping Molecular Dynamics or Monte Carlo as local search operators within larger robotics-inspired exploration frameworks, and adding emerging biomolecular representations, models, and search techniques even beyond the timeline of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed a plug-and-play platform of open-source software elements. The platform facilitates algorithmic research in molecular biology by providing critical software infrastructure to support transformative research in molecular biology and computer science. Specifically, the project addresses the current impasse on reaching the length and time scales needed to obtain a detailed understanding and characterization of the relationship between structure, dynamics, and function in biological molecules central toour biology.


The software platform resulting from our efforts integrates cutting-edge knowledge from two different research communities,computational chemists and biophysicists focused on detailedphysics-based simulations, and AI researchers focused on efficient search and optimization algorithms. Specifically, the developed software elements integrate sophisticated energetic models and molecular representations with powerful search and optimization algorithms for complex modular systems inspired from robot motionplanning and powerful analysis algorithms inspired from high-dimensional geometry and statistical graphics.

The efforts under this project have resulted in ROMEO, a software platform of "Robotics-inspired Algorithms for Modeling BiomolecularStructures and Motions", and several molecular structure data analysis and visualization algorithms, such as "Basin-driven LandsapeReconstruction" (BDR), "Saddle-driven Landscape Reconstruction" (SDR), and others. ROMEO is written in C++ and designed as a plug-and-play platform. The plug-and-play feature supports putting together novel algorithms, such as wrapping Molecular Dynamics or Monte Carlo as local search operators within larger robotics-inspired exploration frameworks, and adding emerging biomolecular representations, models, and search techniques even beyond the timeline of this project. This feature allows ROMEO to be employed by researchers at large to reproduce existing published algorithms for modeling molecular structure and motion modeling, as well as design novel algorithms with which to advance the state of the art. The molecular structure data analysis algorithms such as BDR, SDR, and others are written in Python in order to expand their utilization for diverse application settings by researchers not exclusively interested in modeling molecular structure and motions with ROMEO.

The software elements resulting from this NSF project have been disseminated via publications, workshops, tutorials, and software demos. Specifically, in the last two years, we have organized tutorials at ACM BCB, where participants were given hands-on experience with ROMEO, BDR, SDR, and other software elements. We estimated that about 15 labs have access to these tools and are employing them for in-house modeling and analysis to train students and supplement their own projects. These labs include academic labs(within and outside US) and federal labs (at National Cancer Instituteand Los Alamos Federal Lab).


The activities we have accomplished in this project benefit society at large by advancing current modeling capabilities and in turn current understanding of the role of biomolecules in critical mechanisms in a living and diseased cell. Specifically, the tools we have employed have allowed our collaborators to make discoveries regarding the impact of mutations in molecular mechanisms involving several proteins of central importance to human biology. These tools have also brought focus back to molecular energy landscapes as fertile environments for making predictions regarding function and dysfunction, inspiring most recently a new theme "Landscapes for Machine Learning" to be added to the 2019 annual "Energy Landscapes Workshop" on landscape-driven discoveries.

 


Last Modified: 05/20/2019
Modified by: Amarda Shehu

Images (1 of )
  • A few ROMEO-computed structures are shown along a path that illustrates the rearrangement of the cyanovirin-n protein between two distinct, known structures (with PDB IDs2EZM and 1L5E).
    Kevin Molloy and Amarda Shehu
    Copyrighted
    Amarda Shehu
    ROMEO-computed motions
  • Basins are first computed to identify stable and meta-stable states, which are then employed to obtain a Markov State Model summarizing the structural dynamics of the Met-Enk peptide.
    Lutful kazi Kabir and Amarda Shehu
    Copyrighted
    Amarda Shehu
    Summarization of Met-Enk Structural Dynamics
  • The energy landscape populated by structures sampled in a de-novo setting is reconstructed and visualized here, with basin contours drawn, and the location of the known native structure indicated.
    Nasrin Akhter and Amarda Shehu
    Amarda Shehu
    Landscape Visualization
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project has developed a plug-and-play platform of open-source software elements. The platform facilitates algorithmic research in molecular biology by providing critical software infrastructure to support transformative research in molecular biology and computer science. Specifically, the project addresses the current impasse on reaching the length and time scales needed to obtain a detailed understanding and characterization of the relationship between structure, dynamics, and function in biological molecules central toour biology. The software platform resulting from our efforts integrates cutting-edge knowledge from two different research communities,computational chemists and biophysicists focused on detailedphysics-based simulations, and AI researchers focused on efficient search and optimization algorithms. Specifically, the developed software elements integrate sophisticated energetic models and molecular representations with powerful search and optimization algorithms for complex modular systems inspired from robot motionplanning and powerful analysis algorithms inspired from high-dimensional geometry and statistical graphics. The efforts under this project have resulted in ROMEO, a software platform of "Robotics-inspired Algorithms for Modeling BiomolecularStructures and Motions", and several molecular structure data analysis and visualization algorithms, such as "Basin-driven LandsapeReconstruction" (BDR), "Saddle-driven Landscape Reconstruction" (SDR), and others. ROMEO is written in C++ and designed as a plug-and-play platform. The plug-and-play feature supports putting together novel algorithms, such as wrapping Molecular Dynamics or Monte Carlo as local search operators within larger robotics-inspired exploration frameworks, and adding emerging biomolecular representations, models, and search techniques even beyond the timeline of this project. This feature allows ROMEO to be employed by researchers at large to reproduce existing published algorithms for modeling molecular structure and motion modeling, as well as design novel algorithms with which to advance the state of the art. The molecular structure data analysis algorithms such as BDR, SDR, and others are written in Python in order to expand their utilization for diverse application settings by researchers not exclusively interested in modeling molecular structure and motions with ROMEO. The software elements resulting from this NSF project have been disseminated via publications, workshops, tutorials, and software demos. Specifically, in the last two years, we have organized tutorials at ACM BCB, where participants were given hands-on experience with ROMEO, BDR, SDR, and other software elements. We estimated that about 15 labs have access to these tools and are employing them for in-house modeling and analysis to train students and supplement their own projects. These labs include academic labs(within and outside US) and federal labs (at National Cancer Instituteand Los Alamos Federal Lab). The activities we have accomplished in this project benefit society at large by advancing current modeling capabilities and in turn current understanding of the role of biomolecules in critical mechanisms in a living and diseased cell. Specifically, the tools we have employed have allowed our collaborators to make discoveries regarding the impact of mutations in molecular mechanisms involving several proteins of central importance to human biology. These tools have also brought focus back to molecular energy landscapes as fertile environments for making predictions regarding function and dysfunction, inspiring most recently a new theme "Landscapes for Machine Learning" to be added to the 2019 annual "Energy Landscapes Workshop" on landscape-driven discoveries.
